author: milos88
content:
There are some topics that I want to discuss on the next Monday's call regarding Beacon network:
- The spec says that if client  received `LightClientUpdatesByRange` request and it's missing one of the updates from the range, it must not reply any content
    - This is different from the equivalent [request in the light client spec](https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/blob/dev/specs/altair/light-client/p2p-interface.md#lightclientupdatesbyrange).
    - I would propose that if we have the earlest update from the requested range, we send that one and as many as we have that follow
    - Reason being that nodes usually request more than one update only when the are synching, and any update from the begining of the range is usefull for them, as it will make them progress.
    - And nodes would request all the updates, all the way up to the head of the chain, and peer might be missing the very latest update (and would currently not reply with anything)
- The spec for `LightClientOptimisticUpdate` says that node should compute the current slot based on its local clock and use that slot as a staring point for retrieval
    - What if node is several slots behind? Wouldn't it make sense to request the first slot that is missing?
    - Related to this, if a peer requests the optimistic update for a slot that is earlier than the one we have (we keep only the latest), should we reply with the one we have, or not reply with anything?
